passage_text: A nuclide, also known as an isotope, … is a nucleus with a specified number of both protons and neutrons. So, for example, we know that the element carbon always has six protons in its nucleus; that is what makes it carbon rather than a different element. But it can have different numbers of neutrons. All of the different nuclei that exist that have the same number of protons, but different number of neutrons, are isotopes of whatever atom is being defined by the number of protons in that nucleus.

In nuclear physics, beta decay (β -decay) is a type of radioactive decay in which a proton is transformed into a neutron, or vice versa, inside an atomic nucleus. This process allows the atom to move closer to the optimal ratio of protons and neutrons. Electron capture is sometimes included as a type of beta decay, because the basic nuclear process, mediated by the weak force, is the same. In electron capture, an inner atomic electron is captured by a proton in the nucleus, transforming it into a neutron, and an electron neutrino is released.

Its mass is 1.674927 X 10 −27 kg, which is slightly higher than the mass of a proton. A nucleus of an atom also contains protons, which are positively charged. If there are only protons in the nuclei, the repulsion between those will be higher. Therefore, presence of neutrons is important to bind the protons together in the nuclei. Their properties and interactions are described by nuclear physics. The nucleus consists of Z protons, where Z is called the atomic number, and N neutrons, where N is the neutron number. The atomic number defines the chemical properties of the atom, and the neutron number determines the isotope or nuclide. The terms isotope and nuclide are often used synonymously, but they refer to chemical and nuclear properties, respectively. The atomic mass number, symbol A, equals Z+N.
